Phan Rang - Thap Cham is a former capital of the Cham Empire and lies along the 1A National Highway between
with many Cham people still living in the area.  It has a domestic resort town nearby in the form of
beach, 8 km to the east.  There are also restored and still in use Cham relics.  It is a quieter alternative to
to the south with few foreign travelers stopping. Sometimes tour buses on the way to

has been damaged since the war.  The government has committed to fixing this railway for commercial and tourism purposes but building in 2012 has not yet started since this declaration in 2010.

Po Kluang Garai Cham Tower 8 km west of the town on the road to

near the Thap Cham train station. This is the last capital of the Cham empire before the Vietnamese took over. The location has been restored and has an interesting photography gallery in their otherwise tchotchke filled souvenir area.

Po Rame is a harder to find tower 9 km south on Highway 1A and off the highway a bit in a village.  The temple is still in use although the people tending to it will usually open it up to let you in.
Relax on the sandy beaches when it is empty on the weekdays.

beach next to the Sai Gon - Ninh Chu Hotel has a bunch of local restaurants with live seafood in bowls and tanks for reasonable prices (50,000 - 150,000 dong).  

Various roadside stalls serve up pho, bun, and com tam (broken rice with grilled pork chop) for 15,000 - 25,000 dong.  

The hoards of goats you see wandering roads are served in the restaurants.

These prices are accurate as of June 2012.
